questions.text: Which of the following criteria is included in Gustafson's method but excluded from Dalitz's method of age estimation from teeth?
Which of the following statements BEST describes the value and application of frontal sinus prints?

options.label: A
options.text: Frontal sinus prints are useful for identification, but they change significantly after infections or injuries to the skull.

options.label: B
options.text: Frontal sinus prints are unique to each individual and remain stable after age 15, making them valuable for postmortem identification.

options.label: C
options.text: Frontal sinus prints are only useful for identifying individuals under 15 years of age, as they continue to alter in adulthood.

options.label: D
options.text: Frontal sinus prints provide a general indication of a person's age and sex, but are not unique enough for individual identification.

questions.correct_answer: B. Frontal sinus prints are unique to each individual and remain stable after age 15, making them valuable for postmortem identification.
questions.explanation:
Uniqueness

Unique to each individual

Stability

Permanent and fixed after 15 years of age (Option C)

Resilience

Rarely alter following infection or injury (Option A)

Comparison Method

Antemortem X-ray of skull (occipito-mental plane) compared with postmortem X-rays

Application

Useful for postmortem identification, especially when other methods are unavailable or inconclusive (Option D)

questions.text: A museum curator is organizing an exhibit on the history of forensic science. They come across a set of tools and records from the late 19th century that include calipers, measuring tapes, and detailed cards with various bodily measurements and descriptions. The curator notices that these records consistently include 11 specific measurements, along with descriptions of physical features and photographs. What is the MOST likely purpose of this historical forensic method?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the age and cause of death in archaeological remains

options.label: B
options.text: To create a standardized system for criminal identification

options.label: C
options.text: To classify individuals based on racial characteristics for eugenics research

options.label: D
options.text: To establish a observational method for normal human growth and development

questions.correct_answer: B. To create a standardized system for criminal identification
questions.explanation:
Developer

Alphonse Bertillon

Primary Purpose

To create a standardized system for criminal identification

Principle

• Measurements of various parts of the human body that do not alter after adult age (21 years)

• Observation and recording of descriptive data, photograph and body marks

Measurements Included

• 11 specific measurements including:

  • Height, AP diameter of head and trunk
  • Span of outstretched arms
  • Length of middle finger, left little finger, left forearm and left foot
  • Length and breadth of right ear

• Descriptive data: Color of hair, eyes, complexion, shape of nose, ears and chin

• Body marks: Moles, scars and tattoo marks

• Photographs: Front view and profile view of head

Tools Used

Calipers, measuring tapes, photographic equipment

Historical Significance

First scientific method of criminal identification, paving the way for modern forensic techniques

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is examining a body found in a river. The deceased has multiple tattoos, including a faded amateur tattoo on the arm and a professional tattoo on the chest. The pathologist also notices a partially erased tattoo on the back. Which of the following statements is MOST likely to be true based on the information provided about tattoos?

options.label: A
options.text: The faded amateur tattoo on the arm was likely created using red dye and is about 3 weeks old.

options.label: B
options.text: The professional tattoo on the chest probably used black or blue dye and could be identified in lymph nodes.

options.label: C
options.text: The partially erased tattoo on the back was most likely removed using chemical peeling with trichloroacetic acid.

options.label: D
options.text: All tattoos on the body can be accurately dated to determine the exact time they were created.

questions.correct_answer: B. The professional tattoo on the chest probably used black or blue dye and could be identified in lymph nodes.
questions.explanation:
Age of tattoo
  • Firm union, reddish/bluish scar: 5-6 days
  • Pale, soft and sensitive (tender): 2 weeks-2 months
  • Tough, brownish, glistening, wrinkled and little tender: 2-6 months
  • Tough, white, glistening and non-tender: > 6 months

Dyes Used
  • Common dyes: Indigo, cobalt, carbon, vermilion, cadmium, selenium, Prussian blue and Indian ink
  • Black, blue and red dyes are most commonly employed
  • Depth of penetration: 50-3000 times a minute
  • Pigment can migrate to nearby lymph nodes

Erasure Methods

Surgical methods:

  • Dermabrasion (e.g., tannic acid, silver nitrate, trichloroacetic acid)
  • Complete excision and skin grafting

Non-surgical methods:

  • Production of burns by means of red hot iron
  • Scarification
  • Using carbon dioxide snow
  • Electrolysis
  • Caustic or corrosive substances
  • Chronic eczema may cause tattoo designs to disappear

questions.text: A forensic investigator is examining evidence from a crime scene in a restaurant. The following items have been collected: A wine glass with a partial fingerprint A napkin with a lipstick mark A fork with what appears to be saliva residue The investigator has a suspect in custody but lacks sufficient ridge detail from the partial fingerprint for a conclusive match. Which of the following approaches would be MOST appropriate for the investigator to pursue next?

options.label: A
options.text: Focus solely on analyzing the lipstick mark on the napkin using chelioscopy techniques

options.label: B
options.text: Employ poroscopy to examine the sweat pores on the partial fingerprint from the wine glass

options.label: C
options.text: Disregard the evidence collected and seek alternative means of identification

options.label: D
options.text: Attempt to extract DNA from the saliva on the fork and compare it to the suspect's DNA

questions.correct_answer: B. Employ poroscopy to examine the sweat pores on the partial fingerprint from the wine glass
questions.explanation:
Poroscopy

• Study of pore structure on papillary ridges of fingers as a means of identification

• Discovered and developed by Edmond Locard in 1912

• Ridge characteristics and pores are permanent, immutable and individual

• Useful to establish identity when available ridges do not provide sufficient characteristics

• Ridges contain 9-18 pores

• About 550-950 sweat pores per square centimeter in finger ridges, less (400) in the palms and soles

Cheiloscopy (Lip Prints)

• Study of lip prints for identification purposes

• Lip prints are revealed at points of direct physical contact at crime scenes

• Useful for personal identification

• Credibility not firmly established in forensic science

questions.text: A forensic expert is called to testify in a court case involving disputed fingerprint evidence. During the trial, various aspects of fingerprint analysis are discussed, including abnormalities and development techniques. Which of the following statements about fingerprint abnormalities is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Ridge atrophy with alteration of ridge pattern can be seen in conditions such as celiac disease, dermatitis, and prolonged exposure to certain drugs.

options.label: B
options.text: People with certain genetic disorders like Naegeli-Franceschetti-Jadassohn syndrome may be born without fingerprints.

options.label: C
options.text: Latent prints require additional processing to be rendered visible and are often made from grease, dirt, oil, or blood.

options.label: D
options.text: Development techniques such as VMD, powdering, SPR, and iodine fuming can be used to visualize altered fingerprints

questions.correct_answer: D. Development techniques such as VMD, powdering, SPR, and iodine fuming can be used to visualize altered fingerprints
questions.explanation:
Altered Fingerprints

• Ridge atrophy with alteration of ridge pattern seen in celiac disease, dermatitis, eczema, psoriasis, acanthosis nigricans, scleroderma, and dry and atrophic skin (Option A)

• Prolonged exposure to certain drugs (e.g., capecitabine) may cause loss of fingerprints

• Elderly persons may have fingerprints that are difficult to obtain due to flattening of ridges

Absence of Fingerprints

• People with certain genetic disorders like Naegeli-Franceschetti-Jadassohn syndrome, dermatopathia pigmentosa reticularis, and adermatoglyphia are born without fingerprints (Option B)

• Fingerprints can be erased permanently by criminals through burns, acids, plastic surgery, etc.

Latent Prints

• Require additional processing to be rendered visible

• Often made from grease, dirt, oil, or blood (Option C)

• Can be detected by various methods including powdering, chemical reagents, and alternate light sources

• Fluorescence examination can sometimes detect latent prints

• Development techniques include VMD, powdering, SPR, and iodine fuming

questions.text: Match the following dactylography patterns with their correct type and frequency (%) 1. Loop a. X. 30-35% 2. Whorl b. Y. 5-10% 3. Arch c. Z. 60-70%
questions.explanation:
Permanent impairment of fingerprint patterns

Leprosy, electric injury, and after exposure to radiation.

Ridge atrophy with alteration of ridge pattern

Celiac disease, dermatitis, eczema, psoriasis, acanthosis nigricans,

scleroderma, and dry and atrophic skin.

Loss of fingerprints

Anti-cancer drug- capecitabine

Elderly persons

Fingerprints that are difficult to capture, since the elasticity of skin decreases with age

No fingerprints

Genetic disorders like Baird syndrome

(congenital milia), Zinsser-Cole-Engman syndrome (dyskeratosis

congenita),Naegeli-Franceschetti-Jadasohn syndrome,dermatopathia pigmentosa reticularis, and adermatoglyphia

Pattern Type

Frequency (%)

Loop (Ulnar/radial)

60-70

Whorl

30-35

Arch

5-10

Composite

1-5

questions.text: Match the following ages with their corresponding medicolegal significance: 1. 14 years a) Age of majority and can cast vote 2. 18 years b) Minimum age for appointment as President or Vice-President of India 3. 21 years c) Cannot be employed in factory jobs 4. 25 years d) Age for contesting membership of Parliament 5. 35 years e) Age of marriage for males
questions.explanation:
Age

Medicolegal Importance

14 years

• Employment: Cannot be employed in factory jobs

• Child under the age of 14 can work in non-hazardous industries including some agricultural work as per Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act

14-15 years

• A person can be engaged in non-hazardous factory jobs for a limited period during the day

15 years

• Sexual intercourse even with wife below this age amounts to rape

• A person above 15 years of age can be employed in a factory like an adult, if he has a fitness certificate from a doctor

16 years

• Taking away a male under this age without consent of guardian amounts to kidnapping

18 years

• Statutory rape: Intercourse with a girl below this age, irrespective of whether with or without her consent amounts to rape

• Judicial punishment: Below this age, an offender is juvenile and is tried in juvenile court and if convicted, sent to reformatory school (no imprisonment or death sentence)

• Age of majority except when the individual is under guardianship of the court

• Age of marriage for females

• Can cast vote

21 years

• Age of marriage for males

• If a girl below this age is 'imported' to India from foreign country for the purpose of illicit intercourse, the act amounts to kidnapping (Sec. 366 B IPC)

• Person under the guardianship of the Court of Wards attains majority

25 years

• Age for contesting membership of Parliament and other legislative bodies

• Age limit for entering in some government services

35 years

• According to Punjab Excise Act, a person below this age cannot buy and consume liquor

• Minimum age for appointment as President, Vice-President and Governor of State in India

• Prenatal diagnostic tests/procedures cannot be conducted if the pregnant female is below this age as per the PCPNDT Act

55-65 years

• Age of retirement from services under the government, statutory bodies, autonomous bodies/institutions or from judiciary services

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to court as a witness in a criminal case. Which of the following statements best describes the legal considerations regarding this child's testimony?

options.label: A
options.text: The child cannot give evidence due to being under 7 years old.

options.label: B
options.text: The child's testimony is automatically considered truthful.

options.label: C
options.text: The child can give evidence if the court is satisfied with their understanding.

options.label: D
options.text: The child's testimony will be undertaken by the guardian.

questions.correct_answer: C. The child can give evidence if the court is satisfied with their understanding.
questions.explanation:
Age

Medicolegal Importance

5th lunar month

(12 weeks of pregnancy)

• Till this duration, the decision for termination of pregnancy can be taken by one doctor.

5th-6th lunar month

(20-24 weeks of pregnancy)

• Maximum period of gestation for use of the indication of MTP Act.

2 doctors required to take the decision of termination of pregnancy.

• Above this age, termination is only on therapeutic grounds.

7 months

(28 weeks of pregnancy)

• Fetus is considered to be viable.

• Fetus born after this period, if it does not show any sign of life, is termed stillborn fetus (medically).

10th lunar month

• Fetus at this stage is a full term fetus.

5 years

• Custody of a minor who is below 5 years is with the mother.

7 years

• Below this age, child is not responsible for his criminal act, as he does not understand the nature and consequences of his act.

7-12 years

• Criminal responsibility: A child may or may not be held responsible for his act by the court, depending upon whether the child has attained sufficient maturity to understand the nature and consequence of the act.

10 years

• If a child below this age is removed from his lawful guardian for the purpose of robbing movable property from his/her possession, it will amount to kidnapping .

12 years

• A child under 12 years cannot give valid consent to suffer any harm which may occur from any act done in good faith and for his benefit.

• A child above this age can give valid consent for examination (including medico-legal) and treatment (operative procedures and operations).

questions.text: A team of forensic anthropologists is excavating a site where multiple sets of human remains have been discovered. They need to take precise measurements of various bones to aid in identification and analysis. As they set up their equipment, a junior member of the team asks about the best tool for taking linear measurements of long bones like femurs and tibias. Which instrument should the senior anthropologist recommend for this task?

A forensic anthropologist is tasked with estimating the stature of an unidentified male skeleton. Only the femur is available for measurement. Which of the following multiplication factors should be used to calculate the stature based on the femur length?
questions.explanation:
Bone

Multiplication factor

Femur (Best bone for stature)

3.6-3.8

Tibia/Fibula

4.5

Humerus

5.3

Ulna

6.1

Radius

6.5

questions.text: A partially decomposed body was discovered at a crime scene, and authorities suspected foul play. On examination of dead body, a bullet was retrieved from the body and weapon marks were present on the clothing. To establish that a crime has taken place in this suspected homicide, which of the following is the most crucial factor?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of motive and opportunity for the crime

options.label: B
options.text: Identification of the dead body and proof of death by criminal act

options.label: C
options.text: Eyewitness testimony linking a suspect to the crime

options.label: D
options.text: Detailed reconstruction of the crime scene and sequence of events

questions.correct_answer: B. Identification of the dead body and proof of death by criminal act

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is asked to estimate the age of a deceased infant based on the weight of its teeth, which is found to be 530 mg. Which of the following methods is the most appropriate for age estimation in this case?
questions.explanation:

  • ↳ 2 weeks postnatal

  • ↳ Given the teeth weight of 530 mg, Stack’s method is the most appropriate for estimating the infant’s age.
  • ↳ Boyde’s Method:
  • ↳ Boyde’s Method:
  • ↳ Estimates age by counting cross striations (incremental lines) in the enamel, starting from the neonatal line. These lines represent daily enamel growth. It is suitable for estimating the age of infants by calculating the number of days since the formation of the neonatal line but does not rely on tooth weight.
  • ↳ Estimates age by counting cross striations (incremental lines) in the enamel, starting from the neonatal line.
  • ↳ cross striations (incremental lines)
  • ↳ These lines represent daily enamel growth.
  • ↳ It is suitable for estimating the age of infants by calculating the number of days since the formation of the neonatal line but does not rely on tooth weight.
  • ↳ infants
  • ↳ Since the scenario involves tooth weight, Boyde's method is not the correct approach here. (Option B ruled out)
  • ↳ (Option B ruled out)
  • ↳ Lamendin’s Method:
  • ↳ Lamendin’s Method:
  • ↳ Lamendin’s method is used for age estimation in adults . It relies on measuring the periodontosis height and root transparency, both as a percentage of root height, which is then applied to a regression formula. This method is not applicable to infants or fetuses. (Option C ruled out)
  • ↳ Lamendin’s method is used for age estimation in adults .

  • ↳ Gustafson's Method:
  • ↳ Gustafson's Method:
  • ↳ Gustafson's method is used for estimating age in adults by observing six dental changes, such as: Attrition Paradentosis Secondary dentine. Cementum apposition Root resorption. Transparency of root. Total score = A+ P+ S+ C+ R+ T Like Lamendin's method, it is not appropriate for infants or fetal age determination. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl visits the clinic for a routine examination. During the assessment, the physician notes the development of her upper and lower limb bones. Which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: The head of the humerus fuses with the shaft at 17–18 years.

options.label: B
options.text: The lower end of the radius fuses by 17–19 years.

options.label: C
options.text: The greater trochanter of the femur fuses at 14–15 years.

options.label: D
options.text: The upper end of the fibula fuses at 10–12 years.

questions.correct_answer: D. The upper end of the fibula fuses at 10–12 years.
questions.explanation:
Upper Limb

Centers of Ossification

Age of Appearance

Age of Fusion

Humerus

Head

1 year

At 5–6 years, the three fuse together (conjoint epiphysis), and at 17–18 years, fuse with the shaft. (Option A ruled out)

Greater tubercle

3 years

Lesser tubercle

5 years

Capitulum

1 year

At 14–15 years, all three fuses with the shaft

Trochlea

9–10 years

Lateral epicondyle

10–11 years

Medial epicondyle

5–6 years

16 years

17–19 years (Option B ruled out)

17–19 years

Pisiform

9–12 years

—

Other Carpals

The capitate and hamate bones ossify during infancy, with the capitate appearing first at 36th week(3-4 months age). Between ages 2 and 6, the number of visible carpal bones on an X-ray roughly corresponds to the child's age (e.g., 3 carpal bones indicate approximately 3 years old).

questions.text: Match the following skull sutures with their age of closure 1. Posterior fontanelle a) 2–4 years 2. Anterior fontanelle b) 45–50 years 3. Lambdoid suture c) At birth to 6 months 4. Metopic suture d) 1½–2 years
questions.explanation:
Suture Closure

Age

Posterior fontanelle (occipital)

At birth to 6 months

Anterior fontanelle (bregma)

1½–2 years

Two halves of mandible

1–2 years

Metopic suture (between frontal bones)

2–4 years, may remain unfused

Basiocciput and basisphenoid

18–20 years (females)

20–22 years (males)

Lambdoid suture

45–50 years

Parieto-temporal

60–70 years

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the examination, the physician notes the development of certain bones, particularly focusing on the clavicle and scapula. Based on the provided information, which statement is TRUE regarding the boy’s skeletal development?

options.label: A
options.text: The medial end of the clavicle fuses by 22 years.

options.label: B
options.text: The coracoid base of the scapula fuses at 10 years.

options.label: C
options.text: The xiphisternum fuses at 3 years postnatal.

options.label: D
options.text: The first sternebrae appears between 14–25 years.

questions.correct_answer: A. The medial end of the clavicle fuses by 22 years.
questions.explanation:
Bone

Centers of Ossification

Age of Appearance

Age of Fusion

Sternum

Manubrium

5th-month IUL

60–70 years (manubrio-sternal joint)

1st sternebrae

5th-month IUL (Option D ruled out)

14–25 years (from below upwards; 3rd and 4th–15 years; 2nd and 3rd–20 years; 1st and 2nd–25 years)

2nd and 3rd sternebrae

7th-month IUL

4th sternebrae

10th-month IUL

Xiphisternum

3rd year postnatal

40–45 years (with body) (Option C ruled out)

Clavicle

Medial end

5th–7th week IUL(1st Ossification centre overall to appear in fetus)

20-22 years

questions.text: A pregnant woman has an ultrasound that measures her fetus's Crown Heel Length (CHL) as 40 cm. What is the estimated age of the fetus in months?
A forensic anthropologist is analyzing skeletal remains to determine the sex of an individual. Based on the following rules, which statement is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: According to Ashley’s Rule, females have a sternum length greater than 149 mm.

options.label: B
options.text: Hyrtl’s Law states that males have a sternum body length more than twice the length of the manubrium.

options.label: C
options.text: Krogman’s Table indicates that long bones alone provide 100% accuracy in sexing remains.

options.label: D
options.text: The skull has a higher accuracy rate than the pelvis.

questions.correct_answer: B. Hyrtl’s Law states that males have a sternum body length more than twice the length of the manubrium.
questions.explanation:
Krogman’s Table

The degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains.

Entire skeleton

100%

Pelvis alone

95%

Skull alone

90% (Option D ruled out)

Pelvis plus skull

98%

Long bones alone

80%

(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is tasked with determining the biological sex of skeletal remains found at an excavation site. The skeleton is relatively well-preserved, and specific morphological features are noted. The pelvis shows a wide subpubic angle, a broad sciatic notch, and a wide, circular pelvic inlet. Additionally, the skull has a smaller mastoid process and rounded chin. Based on these skeletal characteristics, which of the following is the most likely biological sex of the individual?

options.label: C
options.text: Cannot be determined without DNA analysis

questions.explanation:
Feature

Male skull

Female skull

General Appearance

Smaller, lighter, walls thinner, smoother

Receding, irregular, rough, less rounded

More capacious (1450–1550 cc)

Less capacious (1300–1350 cc)

Less prominent

Rounded, sharp margins, large

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual with ambiguous genitalia presents for forensic sex determination. Both sex chromatin (Barr body) study and gonadal biopsy are performed. After a thorough examination, it was noted that no Barr bodies were identified, and the gonadal tissue revealed immature seminiferous tubules. Based on this information, which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation?

options.label: A
options.text: The absence of Barr bodies indicates Turner syndrome.

options.label: B
options.text: The individual is chromosomally male but may have androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS).

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of seminiferous tubules confirms chromosomal female sex.

options.label: D
options.text: The absence of Barr bodies automatically excludes mosaicism.

questions.correct_answer: B. The individual is chromosomally male but may have androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS).

questions.text: An unidentified male body is brought to the mortuary for forensic examination. Upon evaluation, it is noted that the orbits of the skull are rounded, the palate is broad, and the teeth exhibit shovel-shaped incisors. The hair recovered from the body is straight and coarse. Based on the forensic findings, what is the most likely racial group of this individual?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Caucasian (White)

Mongolian (Yellow)

Negro (Black)

Skull

Rounded

(Mesaticephalic)

(Brachycephalic)

(Dolicocephalic)

Straight lower face - orthognathism

Teeth
  • Chisel-shaped Incisors
  • Carabelli’s Cusp -accessory cusp in maxillary first molar. Total of 5 cusps.

 
  • Smaller Teeth
  • Narrower Dental Arches
  • Shovel-shaped Incisors
  • Peg-shaped Teeth
  • Taurodontism-body of the tooth is enlarged at the expense of the roots

 
  • Larger Teeth
  • Hypocone- a cusp on the upper molars
  • Larger Teeth
  • Less Frequent Shovel-shaped Incisors

Limbs

Proportional to body

Smaller

Longer

questions.text: A young male is brought to the emergency department unconscious after a car accident. Despite resuscitation efforts, he is declared dead. The medical examiner is called to conduct a post-mortem examination. The patient has no identification, and his body was found far from any populated area. During the autopsy, the cephalic index (CI) of the skull is calculated to be 83. Based on this information, which population ancestry does this person most likely belong to?
questions.explanation:
Skull Shape

Cephalic Index (CI)

Population

Dolichocephalic

(Long-headed)

70-74.99

Pure Aryans, Aborigines, African (Negroid) (Option A)

Mesaticephalic

(Medium-headed)

75-79.99

European (Caucasoid), Chinese, Indians. (Option D)

Brachycephalic

(Short-headed)

80-84.99

East Asian (Mongoloid) (Option C)
